citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Three domestic hoofstock animals were identified as having medical issues by the licensee who was treating or planned
on treating without prior consultation with the attending veterinarian.
• In the petting zoo area, a black goat with brown and white spots was seen coughing slightly with a small amount of clear
nasal discharge and greenish/white discharge at the corner of the right eye. The licensee decided on the treatment plan
for this goat during inspection without first consulting with the veterinarian.
• In the drive thru side, one tan and brown male goat was noted to be emaciated with protruding ribs and readily apparent
bones along the back side. The licensee explained that this goat was treated with varying dewormers for the past year
and was set aside to be culled for failing to gain weight. The veterinarian was not consulted on treatment.
• One red Scottish Highland cow currently under veterinary care in the drive thru area was observed to be thin with the
ribs, hips and back bones protruding sharply beneath the skin. Per the facility, treatment for this animal was initiated by
the facility about 1 week prior to veterinary consultation.
Furthermore, the same amount of nutritional supplement was administered to most of the animals of the facility without
taking into consideration differences in age, weight or species as required in the labeled directions. All rodent animals,
regardless of size or species, were also given the same amount of Vitamin C supplement. The facility could not explain
why this amount was being given and the attending veterinarian was not consulted on dosage.
Medical care that is not being done per the veterinarian’s instructions can result in inappropriate methods to diagnose and
treat conditions. Inappropriate supplement dosages being given to animals could negatively impact their health and
wellbeing. The licensee must consult with the attending veterinarian to obtain a treatment plan for the animals noted
above, to implement a supplement plan based on the specific needs of each animal and then, moving forward, always in
cooperation with the attending veterinarian, the licensee must develop appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose,
and treat diseases and injuries.
Correct by 09/28/2023
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class "C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by NOVEMEBER 25, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
STEPHANIE MAYARD, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Three domestic hoofstock animals were identified as having medical issues by the licensee who was treating or planned 
on treating without prior consultation with the attending veterinarian.  
 
• In the petting zoo area, a black goat with brown and white spots was seen coughing slightly with a small amount of clear 
nasal discharge and greenish/white discharge at the corner of the right eye. The licensee decided on the treatment plan 
for this goat during inspection without first consulting with the veterinarian.  
 
• In the drive thru side, one tan and brown male goat was noted to be emaciated with protruding ribs and readily apparent 
bones along the back side. The licensee explained that this goat was treated with varying dewormers for the past year 
and was set aside to be culled for failing to gain weight. The veterinarian was not consulted on treatment.  
 
 • One red Scottish Highland cow currently under veterinary care in the drive thru area was observed to be thin with the 
ribs, hips and back bones protruding sharply beneath the skin. Per the facility, treatment for this animal was initiated by 
the facility about 1 week prior to veterinary consultation.  
 
Furthermore, the same amount of nutritional supplement was administered to most of the animals of the facility without 
taking into consideration differences in age, weight or species as required in the labeled directions. All rodent animals, 
regardless of size or species, were also given the same amount of Vitamin C supplement. The facility could not explain 
why this amount was being given and the attending veterinarian was not consulted on dosage.  
 
Medical care that is not being done per the veterinarian’s instructions can result in inappropriate methods to diagnose and 
treat conditions. Inappropriate supplement dosages being given to animals could negatively impact their health and 
wellbeing. The licensee must consult with the attending veterinarian to obtain a treatment plan for the animals noted 
above, to implement a supplement plan based on the specific needs of each animal and then, moving forward, always in 
cooperation with the attending veterinarian, the licensee must develop appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, 
and treat diseases and injuries.  
 
Correct by 09/28/2023

This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class "C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by NOVEMEBER 25, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the 
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License 
Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
STEPHANIE MAYARD, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
